data.title: Zaha Hadid's gem in the heart of Cincinnati
data.text:
We moved from Toronto to Cincinnati in 1999, and was a fairy big shock moving from our beloved city, full of museums and art, to what we first considered a very “fly-over” city. 
What we did not know at that time was that the Cincinnati Contemporary Arts Center Board of Trustees awarded, just a year before, world class architect Zaha Hadid with the commission of the new CAC building located at 6th and Walnut.
In case you did not hear of Zaha Hadid and her extraordinary story, let me start with these three buildings designed by her: the aquatic center for the London 2012 Olympics, the Broad Art Museum in Lansing, MI in the U.S., and the Guangzhou Opera House in China.
Zaha was born in Bagdad, Iraq.At the height of her teaching career, in the mid-1980s, Hadid taught at the Harvard Graduate School of Design, and in the 1990s, she held the Sullivan Chair professorship at the University of Illinois at Chicago's School of Architecture. At various times, she served as guest professor at the Hochschule für bildende Künste Hamburg (HFBK Hamburg), the Knowlton School of Architecture at Ohio State University, the Masters Studio at Columbia University, and was the a Visiting Professor of Architectural Design at the Yale School of Architecture. 
Hadid was named an honorary member of the American Academy of Arts and Letters and an honorary fellow of the American Institute of Architects. Zaha was the first woman to receive the Pritzker Architecture Prize, in 2004. 

She died in Miami this year, so the world will not see more buildings from her. 

We are very fortunate to have her work here in the heart of Cincinnati. She built on a terrific tradition in Cincinnati for the modern art: The Contemporary Arts Center was founded as the Modern Art Society in 1939, 60 years before her proposal for the new art center. 
This new location came live in 2003.

data.title: Appreciate Art
data.text: When I lasted visited The Contemporary Arts Center, I learned of children's educational programs that as a parent found interesting.  Displays of the children's work, art for them to explore, workshops etc. There is also several pieces for adults to enjoy, very modern and fascinating.  Also take a walk though the gift shop, especially if you're looking for a unique gift for someone special.  Definitely worth spending a leisurely afternoon and letting your imagination soar!

data.title: Architecturally Speaking and Thought Provoking
data.text: Great architectural building in the heart of downtown Cincinnati with thought provoking art and a cool cafe with good eats. The art center itself is fully funded for a time and now everyone can enjoy it free of charge. What's not to love about that? Take the time, it's worth it.

data.title: Great building & so-so art
data.text: Very attractive architecturally interior, thanks to Zaha Hadid: huge spaces to intimate galleries; shallow stairs (5" rise x 18" depth) that make it appear to go on forever but easily climbed with any labored breathing; back/north wall that extends to the highest floor. Electrical problem in November, 2016 meant LED light installation on that wall was just metal objects of no more than passing interest. The art on all but the top floor is the same nothing but passing interest. The top floor's interactive features make it far more interesting and for kids a big winner. The 21 c hotel museum next door (north of) has far more memorable contemporary art though not the architecture. Valet parking is a good deal if you'll spend more than an hour in the area. The Museum won't keep you that long

data.title: Ever Changing
data.text: Ever changing location with very... unique kinds of art....even if its not your taste of art its still a beautiful location and neat venue for weddings/receptions.

data.title: The fact that it is free is good!
data.text: There were 2 floors open, one for kids and one exhibit on the other floor by one artist. If you are walking by and want something to do for half an hour because you are killing time, this is perfect.  If you have kids, this may be better suited for you.

data.title: Very Good Setting for Contemporary Art
data.text:
The Contemporary Arts Center is basically in the center of downtown Cincinnati.  It's not only convenient and extraordinarily reasonable (i.e. free), but it's very well designed.

Like many contemporary art museums, there is little or no permanent collection, displaying a series of exhibitions that change over time.  That ensures that that the art is always fresh and, of course, contemporary.

The building itself is modern with cool architectural features throughout.  This is largely a blank canvas, so to speak, in that the purpose of the building is to display and showcase the art and to provide a space to do so.  It does this very well.

I really liked the first floor of the building, which is inviting and seems to beckon you to come in, feel artistic, and discuss the art.  There is a nice cafe, lots of couches and seating areas, and plenty of glass to let in natural light.

I visited on September 28, when the only exhibition was by artist Glenn Brown, who has made detailed, grotesque versions of older classically styled paintings.  In early October, they open a new exhibit by photographer Roe Ethridge.  My advice would be to look ahead to see what exhibits are on during your visit, but even if you don't, I'd say come in, look around, and simply leave if it's not to your liking.

This is a very good venue to see contemporary art.

data.title: First time in art gallery
data.text: Incredible exhibition, nice experience. Also, good point about this place - it's for free which personally surprised me a lot 😅

data.title: Is this really the Queen City?
data.text: Everything about this is wonderful.  From the beautiful building, to the restaurant, the workers and the amazing exhibitons they bring in.  Don't miss it.  And after the museum, if you are kid free, go next door to 21C Hotel and have a wonderful cocktail at the copper bar.  It's a perfect afternoon.

data.title: Free Fun
data.text: This arts center is free and its well worth it. The art here is great from local artist to starving arts you will always be amazed at the art in this place. They also have a great bar and its very accessible. The architecture is beautiful.

data.title: Underwhelmed by the art
data.text: I love art museums and am saddened to give an average review to this one. This is my second visit, and both times I was underwhelmed. The museum doesn't have a permanent collection so that perhaps I picked two bad times to visit. Overall, I didn't find anything particularly exciting among the exhibits,  A chacun son gout! Perhaps better luck next time.

data.title: Lovely hidden gem.
data.text: I had spainal surgery 7 weeks ago and my wife and I were looking for a small outing to celebrate our 10th wedding anniversary. We decided on the Contemporary Arts Center. It was an 90 minute drive and didn't look too big for someone who couldn't do a lot of walking. It was PERFECT. Small footprint on 6 floors. The top floor is an interactive hands on children's area so we started on the 5th floor and worked our way back to the first floor coffee shop.  There were several temporary exhibits and we enjoyed all that we saw. The center doesn't appear to have a permanent collection, but rather rotates traveling exhibits throughout the year.  We will definitely be back!  There are a couple of public parking garages within 2 blocks of the center, but as is always the case when driving downtown Cincy, traffic was horrible and the streets were organized by a madman. Bring your GPS and some extra patience. By the way, the center is FREE!

data.title: Great Museum
data.text: Loved his museum and thanks to a group of lovely Cincinnati philanthropists it is now free for the next few years!  Great exhibits and lovely space.  the Un-Museum is a treat for the whole family - a fully interactive space where you can touch the art and create your own.  The lobby is a lovely place to just hang out and grab a coffee or a drink.

data.title: Interesting Pieces at the Various Exhibits
data.text: This museum is now free for everyone, definitely check this place out if you're a local or your traveling. It'll take you an hour or so to get through everything. There are even some exhibits that are fun for the kids! Their restaurant is a great place to grab a drink or lite bite. Great date night activity!

data.title: Amazing Exhibits
data.text: The Contemporary Arts Center is a stop in Cincinnati that you shouldn't miss.  An interesting and very unusual exhibit "Chasing the Whale and Other Endless Pursuits" ended on August 24, 2016.  Another current exhibit is "Life Size Fabric Replicas" with amazing fabric replicas including kitchen appliances, a three story staircase, with unbelievable minuet detail.  The Contemporary Arts Center closes at 4:00PM and we arrived late and missed some exhibits.  Since admission to the Contemporary Arts Center is free, we can easily visit it again at our leisure.

data.title: Great Find
data.text: What a great find after lunch.  We were staying adjacent to the 21C Museum Hotel.  Ate lunch next door and were looking to kill time.  The exhibits were awesome.  Highly recommend taking a trip to the museum and exploring the beautiful exhibits.

data.title: FREE and full of art to make you think and react
data.text: A block over from fountain square, this is a great place to cool off for and hour or two. So much to see and fascinating exhibits. It is an experience rather than a viewing. They had a jazz band playing in the lobby and a coffee bar with light meals too. Loved it.

data.title: Perfect interlude.
data.text: I had 1/2 hour before my next meeting and this was the perfect interlude. Friendly staff. Creative art.   Cafe and lounge to rest your treads. Go.

data.title: Great Museum, Great Staff
data.text:
Visited CAC on a Sunday morning, a family group of 4 adults and an energetic 2 yr old. We went so that she could enjoy the Unmuseum on the 6th floor, designed as an interactive space. We then traveled down through the various spaces to see the other exhibits. Very impressive. The Do Ho Suh exhibition, Passage, was phenomenal.  Definitely a must see, on view through Sept 2016. The staff with whom we interacted, Amy and Brendan,  provided insights and explanations.  The Unraveled: Textiles Reconsidered and the Chasing the Whale exhibitions were also thought provoking, entertaining. Both on display through August. 
We will definitely return, as upcoming exhibitions look very interesting.  All of the staff we met throughout museum were cheerful, knowledgeable, professional. 
Museum space itself is innovative, airy. Free admission on Sundays.

data.title: Would have been great except the staff was rude
data.text: Beautiful fun museum. No admission charge. All a+. Had 4 boys around 10. They ran up the stairs to the children's floor (6) not stopping at any of the other floors. As we followed behind at adult speed we were greeted with snarling security and uncomfortable glares. I can appreciate concern for the exhibits, but the children never went near them except with the adults on the way down.
